children.name: Device/IoT-Centric Security
children.description: Internet of Things (IoT) can be defined as the networked interconnection of everyday objects, equipped with ubiquitous intelligence.

children.name: TG1.1 Unintentional damage/loss of information or IT assets
children.description: This group includes all threats causing unintentional damage including safety and information leakage or sharing due to human errors.

children.name: T1.1.1 Information leakage/sharing due to human errors
children.description: Related to poor/absent patch management, the adoption of weak passwords and wrong authorization configurations.

children.name: T1.1.2 Inadequate design and planning or incorrect adaptation
children.description: Vulnerability to different attacks ranging from buffer overflow to lack of authentication.

children.name: TG1.2 Interception and unauthorised acquisition
children.description: This group includes threats introduced by alteration/manipulation of the communications between two parties.

children.name: T1.2.1 Interception of information
children.description: It considers an attacker intercepting communication between two communicating links.

children.name: T1.2.2 Unauthorized acquisition of information
children.description: IoT can be subject to disclosure of sensitive data, intentionally or unintentionally, to unauthorized parties.

children.name: TG1.3 Intentional physical damage
children.description: In IoT, the physical access to the devices that are spread in a potential uncontrolled environment is more serious than in another domain.

children.name: T1.3.1 Device modification
children.description: Devices might be subject to software reverse-engineering, cloning, device replication, camouflage, and malicious device/node injection

children.name: T1.3.2 Extraction of private information
children.description: IoT devices are often physically unprotected, allowing for private information extraction.

children.name: TG1.4 Nefarious activity/abuse
children.description: It requires active attacks targeting the infrastructure of the victim, including the installation or use of malicious tools and software.

children.name: T1.4.1 Identity fraud
children.description: Identity fraud in IoT primarily refers to both weak user/admin credentials and authentication and identity spoofing.

children.name: T1.4.2 Denial of service
children.description: It can exhaust device's resources, causing performance decrease, loss of data, service outages, as well as safety issues.

children.name: T1.4.3 Malicious code/software/activity
children.description: These threats involve malware, exploit kits, worms, trojans, and exploit backdoors and trapdoors and developer errors.

children.name: T1.4.4 Misuse of assurance tools
children.description: The manipulation of assurance tools can result in scenarios where the malicious behavior of attackers is masqueraded.

children.name: T1.4.5 Failures of the business process
children.description: Improper business processes can damage or cause a loss of assets(confidentiality and integrity of sensor data threats).

children.name: T1.4.6 Code execution and injection (unsecured APIs)
children.description: Code execution and injection are critical classes of attacks that can increase risks.

children.name: TG1.5 Legal
children.description: This group provides for threats resulting from violations of laws and/or regulations, such as the inappropriate use of Intellectual Property Rights and the misuse of personal data.

children.name: T1.5.1 Violation of laws or regulations
children.description: Examples include violations of laws, legislation breach, the failure to meet contractual requirements, personal data abuse, etc.

children.name: TG1.6 Organisational threats
children.description: This group includes threats to the organizational sphere.

children.name: T1.6.1 Skill shortage
children.description: A possible shortage of skilled IoT cybersecurity experts is one of the main threats to IoT.

children.name: Network-Centric Security
children.description: Traditional network environments are characterized by well-defined perimeters and trusted domains.

children.name: TG2.1 Unintentional damage/loss of information or IT assets
children.description: This group includes all threats causing unintentional information leakage or sharing due to human errors.

children.name: T2.1.1 Erroneous use or administration of devices and systems
children.description: Attacks or human-errors are exploited to gain unauthorized privileged access to a system, and can be used as a part of the attack.

children.name: TG2.2 Interception and unauthorised acquisition
children.description: This group includes any attack, passive or active, where the attacker attempts to listen, intercept, or re-route traffic/data.

children.name: T2.2.1 Signaling traffic interception
children.description: Most of the signaling protocols are dated and implemented in an insecure way, thus lacking secuity features.

children.name: T2.2.2 Data session hijacking
children.description: Session hijacking is an attack that is used for gaining unauthorized access between an authorized session connection.

children.name: T2.2.3 Traffic eavesdropping
children.description: It is possible if the traffic is not protected, e.g. user-plane traffic is not encrypted at the radio access level.

children.name: T2.2.4 Traffic redirection
children.description: Redirection of data can be possible by data manipulation when data is not integrity protected.

children.name: TG2.3 Nefarious activity/abuse
children.description: It requires active attacks targeting the network infrastructure of the victim.

children.name: T2.3.1 The exploitation of software bug
children.description: Through software bugs, it is possible to attack the vulnerable device, for instance, DoS, frauds, etc.

children.name: T2.3.2 Manipulation of hardware and firmware
children.description: Once a system is compromised, malware could find vulnerabilities in the firmware allowing for malicious code insertion.

children.name: T2.3.3 Malicious code/software/activity
children.description: One of the main threats against network infrastructures, which will be even more dangerous with emerging networks softwarization.

children.name: T2.3.4 Remote activities (execution)
children.description: In general refers to the process by which an agent can exploit a network vulnerability to run.

children.name: T2.3.5 Malicious code - Signaling amplification attacks
children.description: The amplification effect lies in the fact that DNS response messages may be substantially larger than DNS query messages.

children.name: TG2.4 Organisational threats
children.description: This group includes threats to the organizational sphere.

children.name: T2.4.1 Failures of devices or systems
children.description: System failures include the incidents caused by failures of a system, e.g. hardware and software failures.

children.name: T2.4.2 Supply chain
children.description: A supply chain threat refers to the compromise of an asset with the aim to indirectly damage a certain target.

children.name: T2.4.3 Software bug
children.description: A security bug is a software bug that can be exploited to gain unauthorized access or privileges on a computer system.

children.name: System-Centric Security
children.description: The system is widely used as a synonym of Operating System (OS), or in general, software that enables applications to take advantage of the computation connectivity and storage capabilities of the hardware.

children.name: TG3.1 Unintentional damage/loss of information or IT assets
children.description: This group includes all threats causing unintentional security leakage due to human errors.

children.name: T3.1.1 Information leakage/sharing due to human errors
children.description: Accidental threats caused due to misconfiguration, clerical errors, misapplication of valid rules, and knowledge-based mistakes.

children.name: T3.1.2 Inadequate design and planning or incorrect adaptation
children.description: This threat and its adaptation of a modern cloud-based system can result in threats to managed data.

children.name: TG3.2 Interception and unauthorised acquisition
children.description: This group includes threats introduced by alteration/manipulation of the communications between two parties (including cloud internal communication channels).

children.name: T3.2.1 Interception of information
children.description: It considers an attacker intercepting communication between two communicating links.

children.name: T3.2.2 Unauthorized acquisition of information
children.description: The physical sharing of virtualization or the logical sharing of the cloud enhances the severity of accessing unauthorized data.

children.name: TG3.3 Poisoning
children.description: This group includes all the threats due to configuration/business process poisoning and aiming to alter system behaviors (i.e., at any layers).

children.name: T3.3.1 Configuration poisoning
children.description: It is very difficult to detect and shares a similar impact as unintentional misconfiguration. In most of the cases, it implies a malicious insider.

children.name: TG3.3.2 Business process poisoning
children.description: It refers to business process compromise (BPC), an attack that generates significant monetary profit for the attackers by altering business processes.

children.name: TG3.4 Nefarious activity/abuse
children.description: It requires active attacks targeting the infrastructure at any layers like management hijacking and identity fraud.

children.name: T3.4.1 Identity fraud
children.description: In modern systems, identity handling is more difficult due to the more complex and stratified hierarchical administration of privileges.

children.name: T3.4.2 Denial of service
children.description: It can exhaust system's resources, causing performance decrease, loss of data, service outages, and data availability issues.

children.name: T3.4.3 Malicious code/software/activity
children.description: These threats involve malware, exploit kits, worms, trojans, and exploit backdoors and trapdoors and developer errors.

children.name: T3.4.4 Generation and use of rogue certificatesy
children.description: Certificates are largely used in the cloud to make the service working in a trustful ecosystem.

children.name: T3.4.5 Misuse of assurance tools
children.description: The manipulation of assurance tools can result in scenarios where the malicious behavior of attackers is masqueraded.

children.name: T3.4.6 Failures of the business process
children.description: It is connected with a lack of security governance/awareness and with the need of having users’ behavioral analysis.

children.name: T3.4.7 Code execution and injection (unsecured APIs)
children.description: It is possible to execute code on hypervisor from a malicious VM via memory modification or to compromise the management interface with CSS and SQL injection.

children.name: TG3.5 Legal
children.description: This group provides for threats resulting from violations of laws and/or regulations, such as the inappropriate use of Intellectual Property Rights and the misuse of personal data.

children.name: T3.5.1 Violation of laws or regulations
children.description: It referes to the occurrence of a breach of EU and national laws.

children.name: TG3.6 Organisational threats
children.description: This group includes threats to the organizational sphere.

children.name: T3.6.1 Skill shortage
children.description: A possible shortage of skilled system administrators and managers is one of the main threats to complex systems.

children.name: T3.6.2 Malicious insider
children.description: Insiders operate within a company’s security circle of trust, where they have direct access to resources.

children.name: Data-Centric Security
children.description: The ability of sharing, managing, distributing, and accessing data quickly and remotely are at the basis of the digital revolution.

children.name: TG4.1 Unintentional damage/loss of information or IT assets
children.description: This group includes all threats causing unintentional information leakage or sharing due to human errors.

children.name: T4.1.1 Information leakage/sharing due to human errors
children.description: Accidental threats caused due to misconfiguration, clerical errors, misapplication of valid rules, and knowledge-based mistakes.

children.name: T4.1.2 Inadequate design and planning or incorrect adaptation
children.description: Inadequate design and deployment, including its adaptation, of a Big Data platform, can result in threats to managed data.

children.name: TG4.2 Interception and unauthorised acquisition
children.description: This group includes threats introduced by alteration/manipulation of the communications between two parties.

children.name: T4.2.1 Interception of information
children.description: It considers an attacker intercepting communication between two communicating links.

children.name: T4.2.2 Unauthorized acquisition of information (data breach)
children.description: Unauthorized acquisition of data following data breachesconsiders incidents resulting in a compromise or loss of data.

children.name: TG4.3 Poisoning
children.description: This group includes all threats due to data/model poisoning and aiming to picture a scenario that not adhere to reality.

children.name: T4.3.1 Data poisoning
children.description: Data poisoning is a fundamental threat to all systems building their processes and activities on data.

children.name: TG4.3.2 Model poisoning
children.description: It aims to poison the machine learning models, by poisoning data (Threat T4.3.1) used for the training of the model.

children.name: TG4.4 Nefarious activity/abuse
children.description: It requires active attacks targeting the infrastructure of the victim, including the installation or use of malicious tools and software.

children.name: T4.4.1 Identity fraud
children.description: Personal and profiling data are often used for impersonation fraud, creating big opportunities for identity thieves.

children.name: T4.4.2 Denial of service
children.description: It can exhaust big data platform's resources, causing performance decrease, loss of data, service outages, and data availability issues.

children.name: T4.4.3 Malicious code/software/activity
children.description: These threats involve malware, exploit kits, worms, trojans, and exploit backdoors and trapdoors and developer errors.

children.name: T4.4.4 Generation and use of rogue certificatesy
children.description: They aim to use rouge certificates to access Big Data assets and communication links, causing data leakage, data breaches, misuse of the brand, etc.

children.name: T4.4.5 Misuse of assurance tools
children.description: The manipulation of assurance tools can result in scenarios where the malicious behavior of attackers is masqueraded.

children.name: T4.4.6 Failures of the business process
children.description: This class includes threats to confidentiality and integrity of data.

children.name: T4.4.7 Code execution and injection (unsecured APIs)
children.description: Code execution and injection are critical classes of attacks that can increase risks of greater data breaches.

children.name: TG4.5 Legal
children.description: This group provides for threats resulting from violations of laws and/or regulations, such as the inappropriate use of Intellectual Property Rights and the misuse of personal data.

children.name: T4.5.1 Violation of laws or regulations
children.description: The management of legal aspects is pertinent to the Big Data system and can be considered as a threat to the system itself.

children.name: TG4.6 Organisational threats
children.description: This group includes threats to the organizational sphere.

children.name: T4.6.1 Skill shortage
children.description: A possible shortage of skilled data scientists and managers is one of the main threats to Big Data.

children.name: T4.6.2 Malicious insider
children.description: Insiders are authorized users with legitimate access to sensitive/confidential documents, possibly knowing existing vulnerabilities.

children.name: Application-Centric Security
children.description: Application is denoted as a program or group of programs designed for end-users.

children.name: TG5.1 Unintentional damage
children.description: This group includes all threats causing application malfunctioning or loss of confidentiality/integrity/availability due to human errors.

children.name: T5.1.1 Security misconfiguration
children.description: The problem can target systems at any layer and give attacker the possibility to compromise the system and bypass access control checks.

children.name: TG5.2 Interception and unauthorised acquisition
children.description: This group includes threats introduced by alteration/manipulation of the communications between two parties.

children.name: T5.2.1 Interception of information
children.description: The interception of information is mainly due to weaknesses and flaws in the protocols for communication encryption.

children.name: T5.2.2 Sensitive data exposure
children.description: The most common weaknesses concern is storing/exchange of sensitive data in plain text, as well as how crypto is employed.

children.name: TG5.3 Nefarious activity/abuse
children.description: It requires active attacks targeting the platform of the victim, as well as public interfaces of the hosting platform and applications.

children.name: T5.3.1 Broken authentication and access control
children.description: Broken authentication and access control allow an attacker to compromise an application and the entire system hosting it.

children.name: T5.3.2 Denial of service
children.description: One of the main targets of DoS are applications for a variety of reasons, including economic, political, ideological, etc.

children.name: T5.3.3 Code execution and injection (unsecured APIs)
children.description: Unsecure APIs are supporting criminals in their malicious activities.

children.name: T5.3.4 MInsufficient logging and monitoring
children.description: It reduces the intrusion detection and attack identification performance, decreasing the response and remediation effectiveness.

children.name: T5.3.5 Untrusted compositiony
children.description: Composite services orchestrate atomic services to provide advanced functionalities, introducing additional risks.

children.name: TG5.4 Legal
children.description: This group provides for threats resulting from violations of laws and/or regulations, such as the inappropriate use of Intellectual Property Rights and the misuse of personal data.

children.name: T5.4.1 Violation of laws or regulations
children.description: The most relevant laws include the GDPR and the Regulation on Electronic Identification and Trust Services for Electronic Transactions in the Internal Market.

children.name: TG5.5 Organisational threats
children.description: This group includes threats to the organizational sphere.

children.name: T5.5.1 Malicious insider
children.description: Insiders are authorized users with legitimate access to sensitive/confidential documents, possibly knowing existing vulnerabilities.

children.name: User-Centric Security
children.description: The term users refers to human users of information technologies in a professional context.

children.name: TG6.1 Human errors
children.description: This group includes all threats causing unintentional information leakage or sharing due to human errors.

children.name: T6.1.1 Mishandling of physical assets
children.description: Usually this event has moderate effects, if any, but in few circumstances it can cause severe consequences.

children.name: T6.1.2 Misconfiguration of systems
children.description: All types of systems are systematically misconfigured, often resulting in small failures.

children.name: T6.1.3 Loss of CIA on data assets
children.description: Access privileges are often misused, credentials are managed improperly, and trust is given to wrong person.

children.name: T6.1.4 The legal, reputational, and financial cost
children.description: A security incident may have effects that go well beyond the technical domain and production processes.

children.name: TG6.2  Privacy breaches
children.description: This group includes all threats causing privacy breaches.

children.name: T6.2.1 Profiling and discriminatory practices
children.description: In Europe, GDPR has introduced severe limitations and fines for commercial profiling, which have not stopped the practice of web profiling for advertising purposes.

children.name: T6.2.2 Illegal acquisition of information
children.description: Illegal acquisition of data may happen as a consequence of hacking, of malware exfiltrating information, or of data breaches.

children.name: TG6.3  Cybercrimee
children.description: This group includes all threats due to data/model poisoning and aiming to picture a scenario that not adhere to reality.

children.name: T6.3.1 Organized criminal groups activity
children.description: The use of malware, botnet, ransomware, and hacking is often related to criminal organizations, which are moving online for their illegal activity.

children.name: T6.3.2 State-sponsored organizations activity
children.description: The diffusion of online services and networked systems has enormously increased the possibilities for those willing to access proprietary data.

children.name: T6.3.3 Malicious employees or partners activity
children.description: Inside attackers are likely to exploit better information and higher privileges, increasing the odds of severe consequences.

children.name: TG6.4 Media amplification effects
children.description: This group includes threats coming from nefarious activities.

children.name: T6.4.1 Misinformation/disinformation campaigns
children.description: It considers the relevance that media have in spreading information and amplifying the effect of news in the public opinion.

children.name: T6.4.2 Smearing campaigns/market manipulation
children.description: It relates to the possibility that a smear campaign is directed towards a company with the aim of manipulating the market.

children.name: T6.4.3 Social responsibility/ethics-related incidents
children.description: This represents a new threat for organizations, which might be attacked by crafting an incident based on ethical problems.

children.name: TG6.5 Organisational threats
children.description: This group includes threats to the organizational sphere.

children.name: T6.5.1 Skill shortage/undefined cybersecurity curricula
children.description: Skill shortage in cybersecurity is a problem regularly which regards the majority of organizations.

children.name: T6.5.1 Business misalignment/shift of priorities
children.description: This represents the typical domain of eGovernment, where the aim is to  keep a constant alignment between IT and business goals and between IT processes and the corporate strategy.
